column1: # CASE 2: TIEN RIVER - Multi-Branch Model
# Scientific Justification: Three distributaries are long enough (>60 km)
# to support independent salt intrusion and require separate representation
# per Savenije (2012) convergence-length criterion (Lc/L > 1.5)
# Data sources:
#   - Geometry: Nguyen et al. (2006)
#   - Flow split: Jordan et al. (2019) - 60% of total Mekong discharge
#   - Bifurcation location: My Thuan and Cho Lach
# Column format:
#   ID
# RS (Storage Ratio):
#   - 1.0 for prismatic channels (most river branches)
#   - 5-10 for mangrove/tidal flat areas (increases storage capacity)
# VDB_K (Van den Burgh coefficient):
#   - Controls dispersion decay: D(x) = D0 * exp(-K * x / a)
#   - LOWER K = slower decay = LONGER salt intrusion
#   - HIGHER K = faster decay = SHORTER salt intrusion
#   - Typical range: 0.3-1.0 (Savenije 2005
# 1. Tien Main Stem: Tan Chau (1) to My Thuan Split (2)
# Chezy increased to 65 for reduced friction (calibrated for Mekong
# K=0.8 for main river (freshwater dominated)
# 2. Intermediate Connector: My Thuan (2) to Cho Lach Split (3)
# Short segment carrying flow for both Ham Luong and My Tho.
# K=0.8 for connector (freshwater dominated)
# 3. My Tho Branch: Cho Lach Split (3) to Ocean (4)
# The northernmost branch (Cua Tieu/Dai).
# Chezy = 65 corresponds to Manning n â‰ˆ 0.022 (calibrated Mekong value)
# K=0.75 for steeper salt intrusion gradient (prevents plateau)
# 4. Ham Luong Branch: Cho Lach Split (3) to Ocean (5)
# Splits from the connector
# Chezy = 65 for proper tidal velocity and mixing (lower friction = more salt intrusion)
# K=0.75 for steeper gradient (was 0.50
# 5. Co Chien Branch: My Thuan (2) to Ocean (6)
# Major distributary
